docs.title: Maxwell's Equations in Matter
docs.text:
A constant electric field \(\vec{E}\) will induce a polarization \(\vec{P}\). The measured displacement vector is:

\[\vec{D} = \epsilon_0 \vec{E} + \vec{P}\]

Similarly, for magnetic fields:

\[\vec{B} = \mu_0 \vec{H} + \vec{M}\]

Different books/resources may refer to \(\vec{H}\) and \(\vec{B}\) interchangeably; we will stick with \(B\) and \(H\).

\[ abla \cdot \vec{D} = ho_{free}\] \[ abla \cdot \vec{B} = 0\] \[ abla imes \vec{E} = - rac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t}\] \[ abla imes \vec{H} = \vec{J}_{free} + rac{\partial \vec{D}}{\partial t}\]

docs.title: Constructing Wave Equations in Vacuum
docs.text:
Special case: \( ho = 0\) (no free charge), \(\vec{J} = 0\) (no current)

\[ abla \cdot \vec{E} = 0\] \[ abla \cdot \vec{B} = 0\] \[ abla imes \vec{E} = - rac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t}\] \[ abla imes \vec{B} = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 rac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\]

Taking the curl of \( abla imes \vec{E}\):

\[ abla imes ( abla imes \vec{E}) = - rac{\partial}{\partial t} ( abla imes \vec{B})\]

Using the vector identity \( abla imes ( abla imes \vec{E}) = abla ( abla \cdot \vec{E}) - abla^2 \vec{E}\):

\[ abla ( abla \cdot \vec{E}) - abla^2 \vec{E} = -\mu_0 \epsilon_0 rac{\partial^2 \vec{E}}{\partial t^2}\]

Since \( abla \cdot \vec{E} = 0\):

\[ abla^2 \vec{E} = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 rac{\partial^2 \vec{E}}{\partial t^2}\]

Similarly for the magnetic field:

\[ abla^2 \vec{B} = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 rac{\partial^2 \vec{B}}{\partial t^2}\]

Linear Polarization:

\[\vec{E} = E_x \hat{x}, \quad \vec{B} = B_y \hat{y}, \quad \vec{k} = k_0 \hat{z}\]

Assume separation of variables:

\[E_x(\vec{r}, t) = R(\vec{r}) T(t)\]

Plugging into the wave equation:

\[ abla^2 [R(\vec{r}) T(t)] = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 rac{d^2}{dt^2} [R(\vec{r}) T(t)]\]

Since \( abla^2\) acts only on spatial variables and \(d^2/dt^2\) acts only on time:

\[T(t) abla^2 R(\vec{r}) = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 R(\vec{r}) rac{d^2 T(t)}{dt^2}\]

Divide both sides by \(R(\vec{r}) T(t)\):

\[ rac{ abla^2 R(\vec{r})}{R(\vec{r})} = \mu_0 \epsilon_0 rac{1}{T(t)} rac{d^2 T(t)}{dt^2} = -k^2\]

Time-dependent equation:

\[ rac{d^2 T(t)}{dt^2} + rac{k^2}{\mu_0 \epsilon_0} T(t) = 0\]

Letting \(c = 1/\sqrt{\mu_0 \epsilon_0}\), we have:

\[ rac{d^2 T(t)}{dt^2} + \omega^2 T(t) = 0, \quad \omega = rac{k}{c}\]

Solutions:

\[T(t) = A \cos(\omega t) + B \sin(\omega t) \quad ext{or} \quad T(t) = C e^{i \omega t} + D e^{-i \omega t}\]

We usually adopt the convention:

\[T(t) = D e^{-i \omega t}\]

Monochromatic electric field:

\[E_x(\vec{r}, t) = R(\vec{r}) e^{-i \omega t} = R(\vec{r}) e^{-i 2\pi u t}\]

Polychromatic light:

\[E_x(\vec{r}, t) = \sum_\ell D_\ell( u) e^{-i 2\pi u t} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} D( u) e^{-i 2\pi u t} d u\]

Frequency-domain representation:

\[ ilde{E}_x(\vec{r}, u) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} E_x(\vec{r}, t) e^{i 2\pi u t} dt\]

docs.text: Instructor: Dr. Shuford Term Spring 2026

docs.title: Introduction/Review
docs.text: • Lecture 1

docs.title: Introduction to the course and beginning material
docs.text: In this course we will mostly cover statistical thermodynamics (equilibrium statistical mechanics). Non-equilibrium statistical mechanics may be covered briefly towards the end of the course if time permits.

docs.title: Review of Quantum Mechanics
docs.text: Before starting statistical mechanics, we review quantum mechanics. Thermodynamics will average quantum mechanical properties over a large number of atoms and provide mathematical relationships between QM and measurable properties.

docs.title: Postulates of QM
docs.text:
1. State Function: The state of a system is described by a wavefunction \(\Psi(\vec{r},t)\) that depends on position and time.

  2. Observables: To every classical observable, there corresponds a linear, Hermitian operator \(\hat{A}\). The expectation value obeys \(\int f^* (\hat{A} g) \, d\tau = \int g^* (\hat{A} f) \, d\tau\)

  3. Measurement: A measurement of \(\hat{A}\) yields an eigenvalue \(a\):\(\hat{A} \Psi = a \Psi\)

  4. Expectation Value: If \(\Psi\) is normalized, \(\langle \hat{A} \rangle = \int \Psi^* \hat{A} \Psi \, d\tau\)

Example: position \(\langle \hat{x} \rangle = \int \Psi^* x \Psi \, d\tau\)

  1. Time Evolution: The wavefunction evolves according to the time-dependent Schrödinger equation: \(i \hbar \frac{\partial \Psi}{\partial t} = \hat{H} \Psi\)

docs.title: Working with the Hamiltonian Operator
docs.text:
The one-dimensional Hamiltonian:

\[\hat{H}(x) = -\frac{\hbar^2}{2m} \frac{d^2}{dx^2} + V(x)\]

where the first term is the kinetic energy operator and the second is the potential energy operator.

We assume separation of variables:

\[\Psi(x,t) = \psi(x) f(t)\]

Plugging into the time-dependent Schrödinger equation:

\[i \hbar \frac{d}{dt} [f(t) \psi(x)] = \hat{H} [f(t) \psi(x)]\]

Recognizing that \(f(t)\) has no spatial dependence and \(\psi(x)\) has no time dependence:

\[i \hbar \frac{df}{dt} \psi(x) = f(t) \hat{H} \psi(x)\]

Divide both sides by \(f(t)\psi(x)\):

\[\frac{i \hbar}{f(t)} \frac{df}{dt} = \frac{\hat{H} \psi}{\psi} = E\]

where \(E\) is a separation constant (the total energy). This yields two separate equations:

  1. Time-Dependent Equation:
\[i \hbar \frac{df}{dt} = E f(t) \quad \implies \quad f(t) = A e^{-i E t / \hbar}\]
  1. Time-Independent Schrödinger Equation:
\[\hat{H} \psi(x) = E \psi(x)\]

Full solution:

\[\Psi(x,t) = \psi(x) e^{-i E t / \hbar}\]

docs.title: Born Interpretation of the Wavefunction
docs.text:
• \(|\psi(x)|^2\) is the probability density, giving the probability of finding a particle between \(x\) and \(x + dx\):
\[P(x) dx = |\psi(x)|^2 dx\]
  • Stationary States: The probability density is time-independent:
\[|\Psi(x,t)|^2 = |\psi(x)|^2\]
  • Time-Dependent Solutions (general):
\[\Psi(x,t) = \hat{T} \exp\left(-\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_0^t \hat{H}(\vec{r},t') dt' \right) \Psi(0)\]

docs.title: Dirac Notation
docs.text:
• Bra: \(\langle \psi | = \psi^*\)
  • Ket: \(|\psi\rangle = \psi\)
  • Matrix Element:
\[\langle \psi_i | \hat{A} | \psi_j \rangle = \int \psi_i^* \hat{A} \psi_j \, d\tau\]
  • Kronecker Delta:
\[\langle i | j \rangle = \delta_{ij} = \begin{cases} 1 & i = j \\ 0 & i \neq j \end{cases}\]

Wavefunctions must be continuous, single-valued, and have continuous first derivatives. They must be quadratically integrable (\(\langle \psi | \psi \rangle\) exists), except in the case of unbounded free particles.

docs.title: Example: Permutation Operator
docs.text:
The perumtation operator is: \(\hat{P}_{ij}\)

\[\hat{P}_{ij}^2 = 1, \quad \hat{P}_{12} f = c f\]

Applying the operator twice:

\[\hat{P}_{12} \hat{P}_{12} f = \hat{P}_{12} (c f) = c^2 f = f \implies c = \pm 1\]

docs.title: Pauli Principle
docs.text:
• Fermions (half-integer spin): The total wavefunction must be antisymmetric under particle exchange.
  • Bosons (integer spin): The total wavefunction must be symmetric under particle exchange.

Example: For electrons, the total wavefunction must be antisymmetric with respect to the exchange of any two electrons.
